title: How influential was Black Sabbath to metal? - Quora

response.answer_text: Aesthetically, they were obviously a huge driving force for the genre, as were a bunch of other bands buried under the success of Sabbath such as Wicked Lady and Coven. Thy created a sound with massive sounding guitar riffs and an “off” vibe, serious groove and a lot of times, slower tempos. The genres Stoner Metal, Doom Metal and Sludge essentially are worship genres to what Black Sabbath released in their early days up until their Sabotage album. In terms of the sound, it started to develop ever since The Kinks wrote You Really Got Me where the guitarist slashed his speakers to get a distorted sound (mind you, this was at a time when distortion wasn’t a favorable quality and the amplifiers were designed to not distort at loud volumes.). The sound was further innovated by legends such as including Jimi Hendrix, Paul McCartney and Keith Richards. The introduction of fuzz pedals greatly sped up the progression of this sound. As for their influence on heavy metal, I’d attribute that to Deep Purple, Led Zeppelin, Motorhead, and Black Sabbath equally. The attitude, speed and in Black Sabbath’s case, the tri-tone basically forged what eventually became known as heavy metal. But on a personal note, Judas Priest is a biggest influence on what traditional heavy metal eventually became.

They were the most influential group to Heavy Metal at all! Tony Iommi was even awarded with Honorary Doctorate of Arts by Coventry University on 19 November 2013 because of this. The honorary degree was "in recognition of his contribution to the world of popular music." It added this recognised "in particular his role as one of the founding fathers of heavy metal music and his status as one of the industry's most influential figures". Source: BBC Black Sabbath's Tony Iommi in Coventry University degree honour - BBC News
